title.title: The Correspondence of John Hunt and Joshua Evans

msIdentifier.institution: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

projectDesc.p: The correspondence of Quaker ministers John Hunt and Joshua Evans are stored at the Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College. With the generous support of H. David and Joyce E. Hunt, Library staff scanned and transcribed these letters in 2023 and encoded the text in TEI. The 2023 project also included researching individuals mentioned in the text to create and update records about them in the Social Networks and Archival Context website

div.p: Having an opportunity to to thee. I feel a willingness to embrace the same, but I feel a little at a loss how to address myself to such an elderly person as thou art, not having anything in particular on my mind but good will, dear friend thee has been a frequent subject of my thought since I saw thee last, for thee was in a very poor state of health then, and I have heard that thou hast had a bad spell of sickness since, the hearing of which somewhat affected me, to think thou art so much afflicted now in the absence of thy husband, and I believe I do a little feelingly sympathize with thee in thy present lonesome situation, who art separated from such an agreeable companion for a season. But I hope thee will give him up freely, for I believe he is where he ought to be and in the Lordâ€™s work & service, which at times and seasons is a comfort to my mind, to find there are some who are willing to give up their time for such a glorious work & service. For there are so many of us that are fulfilling the lust of the flesh and the lust of the eye and the pride of life, which I acknowledge to be very great folly, and am at times willing to forsake them, but the flesh is weak. Likewise Joseph Evans hath been frequent in my thought since I was up there last, being in some measure sensible of his great loss can in some degree sympathize with him, as he is deprived of such a good wife, an agreeable companion and affectionate mother to their dear children. But his and our great loss, I hope, is her gain who is gone from works to reward. These may likewise inform thee that we are favored with a good state of health at this time, which I esteem a great blessing, especially now when the Smallpox hath been so thick in our neighborhood, and Margaret hath been favored to escape it. Our friends here are generally well. We have got moved and live pretty comfortable and should be glad to see thee down here as soon as is convenient. We have not heard from Father Evans this good while, nor any of you; therefore, a few lines from you would be very acceptable, as it is the greatest comfort that absence affords true friends. Please to give my kind love to Joshua Evans and enquiring friends. Margaret, not having time to write, requests me to give

closer.salute: In haste I conclude and subscribe myself thy son-in-law,
